raw_text:
Hamm bows out for US
 
 Women's football legend Mia Hamm has played her final game.
 
 Hamm, 32, who officially retired after this year's Athens Olympics, took to the field for the last time to help the US claim a 5-0 win over Mexico. Hamm ends her career as the most prolific scorer - male or female - in international football, with 158 goals in 276 games for the US. She was twice Fifa women's player of the year and won the World Cup in 1991 and 1999 and two Olympic golds. On her retirement, Hamm said: "There are mixed emotions. There are things in your life that you have had to put on the back-burner and you can focus more time and energy on that now. "I have to see what is out there and not commit to everything at the beginning." The friendly also saw the end of Julie Foudy and Joy Fawcett's US careers. Hamm will now embark on a new life with husband, Chicago Cubs shortstop Nomar Garciaparra, who was in the stands to watch her final game. He has just agreed a new deal with the Cubs after joining them in July.
llama3.2:1b: Mia Hamm played her final US football match at age 32, retiring after this year's Athens Olympics.
She is the most prolific scorer - male or female - in international football with 158 goals for the US.
Hamm has won multiple awards, including two World Cups and two Olympic gold medals.
llama3.2:3b: Mia Hamm retired from women's football after the 1999 World Cup.
She played 276 games for the US scoring 158 goals and won two Olympic golds, two World Cups, and was named Fifa women's player of the year twice.

Her retirement also marked the end of Julie Foudy and Joy Fawcett's US careers.
Hamm will now focus on her life with husband Nomar Garciaparra who recently signed a new deal with the Chicago Cubs.

She said, "I have done my job so far - focus more time on my future career."

She now joins Nomar Garciaparra, who had previously retired but is signing a new contract with baseball's Chicago Cubs.
qwen2.5:3b: Hamm, a 32-year-old women's football legend and former US captain, played her final international match against Mexico, helping the US win 5-0 and ending her career as the most prolific scorer in female international football with 158 goals.
Hamm was twice FIFA Women's Player of the Year and won World Cups in 1991 and 1999 and Olympic golds.
Her final game also marked the end of Julie Foudy and Joy Fawcett's careers.
On retirement, Hamm expressed mixed emotions but plans to focus on personal matters.
Hamm will now start a new chapter with her husband, Nomar Garciaparra, who attended her farewell match.

She has made 158 goals and played 276 matches, reaching a record-breaking finish with 5-0 wins.
The player is a double-favorite of FIFA women's players and has won the World Cup in 1991 twice and 19,999 other international titles.
On retirement, Hamm says: "There are mixed emotions; things that have taken up more time and energy than most are getting on the back-burner now.
I am compelled to see what is out there, and I will not hesitate to commit to everything at the beginning."
They also watched the end of Julie Foudy and Joy Fawcett's US careers.
